qas.question: Will mainstream political parties not cooperate towards outsider parties if they are too extream?

answers.text: mainstream political parties may form an informal cordon sanitarian which applies a policy of non-cooperation towards those "Outsider Parties"

qas.question: which  outsider parties considered unacceptable to work with?
What has been increasingly abandoned in the past two decades?

plausible_answers.text: the pressure to construct broad coalitions

qas.question: What has caused far-right parties to be abandoned over the past two decades?
What kind of democracies were created after the formation of the EU?
What groups have Outsider Parties not wanted to cooperate with recently?
What did Outsider Parties form because they didn't want to cooperate with government?
What kind of policy do Outsider Parties usually have towards the government?

context: Furthermore, in the case of <a1_0><b5_0>far-right, far-left and regionalism<a1_0/> parties<b5_0/> in the national parliaments of much of the European Union, <a0_0>mainstream political parties may form an informal <b6_0>cordon sanitarian<b6_0/> which applies <b7_0>a policy of non-cooperation<b7_0/> towards those "Outsider Parties"<a0_0/> present in the legislature which are viewed as 'anti-system' or otherwise unacceptable for government. <a2_0>Cordon Sanitarian<a2_0/>, however, have been increasingly abandoned over the past two decades in <b4_0>multi-party<b4_0/> democracies as <b3_0>the pressure to construct broad coalitions<b3_0/> in order to win elections – along with the increased willingness of outsider parties themselves to participate in government – has led to many such parties entering electoral and government coalitions.
